title: How many states will have reported more total COVID-19 cases for September 2020 than for June 2020?
preds: Another couple of statues just tipped over putting the number at minimum 45.  Happy fall!

updating with data through sep 29th. Sep actuals + 7day avg rate for the remaining day.
Without data restatements, this is over.
Central estimate is 44.5.
44 are already over june levels in today's data.
New York and Nevada crossed over, already over 44. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1R05etdtiuyQiQ0MOfnB-D2xCU3N3E-wjLuo9SBFyo6s/edit?usp=sharing
Currently 43 states already surpassed June levels.  Chances are one more will make it over as several are quite close and still have to report todays numbers.
44 'States' have met the criteria. And Louisiana will probably exceed its June totals tomorrow. 45 expected. -1% to 36-43, +1% to 44 or more.

Recap: with Sep 28th data yesterday, it was 42 confirmed and down to CT, LA and NY to deliver at least 2 more territories for the required 44 and bin 7. CT required 46 over the remaining 2 days, LA 759, and NY 981 to exceed the June count. With Sep 29th data out now, the required count has changed to nil for CT, nil for NY (total 44 states confirmed) and 225 for LA. Total is either 44 or more likely 45, and therefore 100% in bin 7.

Technically at 43 as of yesterday. CT is under by 1%, LA & NY under by 4%.
45 cases in CT today puts us at 44 (they had 560 cases yesterday.) Clearly this question is not being actively tracked by the crowd.

According to the John's Hopkins GitHub repository (https://github.com/CSSEGISandData/COVID-19) we already have 44 states above their September totals. But for this questions we're using the COVID Tracking Project, and it seems like they're only at 43 states. I would say it's 100% that it'll be 44 or more because of my John's Hopkins data set analysis, but I don't want to have to re-do all the analysis with the other data set, so I'll just leave 5% in case I'm missing some discrepancy between the data sets.

updating with data through 9/28.
44.5 is central estimate.
3 states close based on abs difference between sep forecast (actuals plus rate of last 7 days) and june, and variance in daily reported cases in sep: CT, LA, WA.
All 3 would need to end up below june. 9% chance of that by my calculations: 29%×37%×83%=9%.
A good lesson from this market. If the outcome depends even a little on Trump's decision making process, add uncertainty!
Already at 42 states with higher figures vs June. NY and CT should fall in as well given current rate.

June was really bad. September is even much worse. I didn´t expect it to be that bad at all. And still so many deaths (similar to June), so it´s not only because of more testing. It should have got much better in summer like almost everywhere else. And the fatality rate should have gone down much more like almost everywhere else as well. 
It´s really depressing. 100% depressing.
What a depressing forecast to make

560 new cases in CT on September 28th means we don't need NY anymore for a total of 44. NV confirmed in. LA low count but not low enough to jeopardize anything. To put the CT "outlier" into context: if CA or ME had a day like this tomorrow, they would be candidates to take the count to 46 or even 47.

Updating with latest through the 27th. Actuals plus daily rate of last 7 days.
44 is central estimate.
Considering the absolute difference between sep forecast and june, and variance in daily cases, only 3 states are close and only 1 of those needs to surpass june to hit 44+ bucket. LA, CT, WA. Given their st devs, I landed at 83% of at least one of the 3 exceeding June.
Based on what I'm seeing, we are at 41 states and it seems very likely to get to 43, but unclear if it is going to go over (NY seems to be the tipping point).

42 states already exceeded June. Louisiana, Nevada, and New York all look very likely to exceed June numbers too. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1R05etdtiuyQiQ0MOfnB-D2xCU3N3E-wjLuo9SBFyo6s/edit?usp=sharing

41 'States' have met the criteria. 4 states are close, with 3 (CT, LA, and NV) likely to exceed their June totals by the 29th, and 1 (NY) likely to reach it by the 30th. -4% to 36-43 and +4% to 44 or more.

New data out and New Jersey made it over the line. As expected no cases reported over the weekend in CT, but any correction for that in the coming 3 days should be enough. The "cliffhanger states" are now:
New York 866 on 27th, 605 average required per day
Nevada 373 on 27th, 121 average required per day
Louisiana 923 on 27th, 333 average required per day
Connecticut no cases, 202 average required per day As you can see from the required versus recorded, all except CT look fairly safe. With 41 over the line, that's 44 or 45 in total, with 43 becoming somewhat unlikely, i.e. a run of low reporting days in NY or something of that sort. DC is almost certainly out, as we would need to average 89 cases per day versus a Sep average of 52 and last of 35.

Update of a spreadsheet [1] that uses COVID Tracking data [2]. I have updated it using data available up to 27 Sept 2020 to find out how many states/territories (55 total) have had more cases Sept 1-Sept 27 than June 1-June 27. As of 27 September, 46 states/territories have had more cases thus far in September than at this same point in June. This number was 45 states/territories on 24 September, 44 states/territories on 22 September, 44 states/territories on 18 September, and 43 states/territories on 14 September. Bin 7 is most likely, but bin 6 is still definitely a possibility. [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ysBVQJDZF6xcvhhu8DOSPuY1OnivzdoTQek3lGszQCI/edit?usp=sharing
[2] https://covidtracking.com/data
Currently 43 states are higher and it seems likely that at least one of DC, Louisiana, Nevada or New York will tip over in the next few days.

41 states have more cases in September than they did in June as of today (9/27). 3 states are very close to passing their June totals: Connecticut, New York, and New Jersey. Because these states are all so close to each other, I suspect they'll all follow the same trend. Meaning, if one state surpasses the June total, all three will.  This means that I don't need to combine separate predictions for each state, the question just becomes: Do you think the tri-state area will have more cases in September than they did in June? And the only options are No (in which case, our answer to the original question is "between 36 and 43") or no (in which case our answer is "44 or more").  Based on the trends over the next few days, I think it's certainly more likely than not that cases increase in these states. However, it's so close to the line that I'm hesitant to go all-in on "44 or more" so I've settled on the above numbers.

By my count there are 9 states in the definite NO column -- AZ, CA, DC, FL, MA, NH, NM, VT, WA.
There are 3 states that have an 80+% chance of being YES -- LA, NC & NV.
ME is more than likely (70%) a NO.
NY is the only remaining toss-up (50/50).
The remaining 41 states are 97+% likely to be YES (many are already there). Adding the 41 definite YES's to the 3 likely YES's gives 44.  If one of these puts up better numbers over the next week there is still NY at 50/50, and ME with a 30% chance.  So I'll push up the odds for the "44 or more" bin.  The final answer could be as low as 41 or as high as 46, but those outcomes seem highly unlikely.

TX had and odd reporting day: although TX DSHS reported 3,964 new cases for 22 September 2020, they also announce the following:
"13,622 older cases recently reported by labs were included in the statewide total but excluded from statewide and Harris County new confirmed cases (507)."
This meant a new cases-number of 17,820 new cases for Texas on 22 Sep according to covidtracking.com's kind of counting, although that might - for this question - be a bit unfair, since the older cases may already date back to August or even earlier. However,  Texas surpassed the outstanding number of confirmations, 10,281 just yesterday and politely reminds us that revisions of testing and/or methodology, belated test results, error correction etc. can have a significant influence on the states' result and thus on the total question resolution. Here's a list of the relevant states and their probabilities of observing a major revision of cases before 01 October 2020 (sorted by my guesstimate probability, descending order): /FL (90%; "On September 1, 2020, the Florida Department of Health announced that Quest Diagnostics had reported nearly 75,000 backlogged tests dating as far back as April.
Per reporting, the number of pending tests (available in our API and CSVs) may include only results from public labs, and may therefore be an undercount.")
The backlog seems to be done with on 01 September 2020 with an extraordinarily high day value 7,569 new cases.
If this repeats, due to e.g. the hurricane situation impact on the coastal areas since mid-September: 75k backlogged tests, at at positivity rate of ~14%, could easily mean 10,000 additional confirmed cases, which would definitely switch FL from the OUT-group to the IN-group. Two questions remain: Will the backlogged cases be reported in one daycount, or resolved step by step? And, how long can it take to resolve this backlog (it was reported on 01 Sep 2020), and will the additional reports be included in the covidtracking.com figures soon enough to affect the resolution of this question?

Starting with the assumption of 100% likelihood that September would exceed its June figures for a given state, my approach centered on discounting and crediting this total based on certain empirical indicators - Num of previous months exceeded change, Num of months where trend reversed, and Estimated Sept final exceeds - explained further below.      After determining each state’s “Sept Max” (i.e. its June figure) for it to not exceed June’s, I was able to quickly isolate those states which had already violated based on the latest Sept data. Hence 100% prob. for these. Num of previous months exceeded change:
Compared the change from August to Sept Max against historical monthly changes since Feb. A tally of those previous months with greater change served as a discount. My rational is that whether on a downward or upward trend, history supports the possibility of achieving the Sept threshold (w/o necessarily surpassing it) despite the size of movement required.   Num of months where trend reversed:
Assessed the direction of suggested change (August to Sept Max). Where it would reverse the trend - when measured against the monthly avg change since June - compared this against historical to tally those months which also had a reversal in month-to-month change. This tally would also serve as a discount because , similarly to above, evidences it as possible which could subsequently prevent September from exceeding. Estimated Sept final exceeds:
Leveraging the obvious benefit of it now being September, calculated the daily rate and, after accounting for days remaining, estimated a final tally of cases for the month. Where this exceeded Sept Max, a credit towards the likelihood of actual exceeding was assigned.    For a given state, its final probability of exceeding its June figures took the net sum of tallies from above to deduct from the 100% assumption after dividing them by the number of months since Feb. Interpreting the percentages assigned to each state tally bucket as the likelihood of that bucket representing all states with higher Sept figures, I sorted the calculated state probabilities from highest to lowest to determine where to begin apportioning. For instance, if 29 states have assigned 100% probability, all buckets with a cut-off below 28 would be given 0 probability. The next qualifying bucket would contain a tally up to its cut-off that’s weighted by the individual state probabilities. This would be repeated for each subsequent bucket until accounting for all 56 state-level probabilities. Lastly, each bucket total is displayed as a percentage of the sum to ensure a grand total of 100%.

Modifying my methodology a bit: right now I count about 20 states that are already above June numbers. Thus the question is what happens with the remaining 35. Depending on the scenarios I play with (basically using different rates of exponential decrease or growth), I end up with between 40 and 43 states above the June punchline. If I remove the 20 that are already a done deal, this gives me 20 to 23 states over 35 where things can change. What I then do is to simply model their outcome as a fixed probability p1 = 20/35 or p2=23/35, and using the binomial distribution for the states where things can change I get the probabilities I have used above.

"DSHS revised its method for reporting Total Tests, effective 9/14/2020. DSHS will now only report electronic lab results that have passed quality checks and have cleared into the state’s system of record, NEDSS, the National Electronic Disease Surveillance System. This improvement is possible due to recent upgrades to NEDSS, which now processes data more quickly. The revised methodology ensures data is fully deduplicated and that only tests that passed through the data submission quality checks are counted in Total Tests. Test submissions that error out of the system due to data quality issues will not be counted until they are successfully resubmitted and pass validation requirements. Additionally, Total Tests will no longer include faxes or aggregate counts received by various labs since there is not a timely way to complete data quality checks. "

Nine days into September, a second refined estimate and extrapolation is possible. Of 55 states and territories under consideration (American Samoa (AS) is obviously obliterated from the list), as of 09 September 2020 8 are likely not to surpass their June case number (mainly New England states + D.C., NM, AZ)
1 of which (Massachusetts (MA)) is almost impossible technically
47 states and territories are likely or very likely to surpass their June number of cases
13 of which have already surpassed their June value (AK, KS, KY, MI, OK, SD, and the prevoious GU, HI, MO, MT, ND, VI, WV) which already rules out bin 2
I counted 20 states and territories which have decelerated significantly their case growth during 05 to 09 September 2020, 10 of which are now considered in a range of possibility to change outcome (to "less in September than in June"). I counted 15 states and territories which have accelerated significantly their case growth during 05 to 09 September 2020, 4 of which are now considered in a range of possibility to change outcome (to "more in September than in June"). At the same time, the acceleration is re-confirming the previously expected excess of cases in the other 11 states, which I will consider as a given from now on.
4 other states confirmed their path towards a lower outcome (DC, ME, NM, VT) which I will also consider as a given.
However, 3 states that I expected to be in the "out-group", failed my expectations and -at least preliminarily - switched to a path towards the "in-group": NJ, RI, WA.
I have previously considered NY as safe below, but it's getting closer there, so NY replaces ME in my "indiscriminate" group under close scrutiny: CA, FL, NJ, MP, NJ, UT plus I add CT.
As of 09 September these seven stand as follows:
CA: out (since trend is declining), 
CT: out (strong short-term upward trend, yet still below June value expected)
FL: out (since trend is declining),
NY: in (since decline may not be large enough or stop),
MP: in (1 new case since last forecast, leads to 10 projected cases compared to 8 in June),
NJ: in (currently strong acceleration in new cases, a significant slow down would be compulsory to switch to the out-group again),
UT: currently "in" at an virtually unchanged rate but by a very slight margin; little changes in e.g. testing could tip it to any direction. As a result, in total, it's getting more complicated:
The group of 9 which seemed likely not to surpass their June case number (mainly New England states + D.C., NM, AZ) has shrunk to 5.
3 states from the indiscriminate group included, there are 8 states with increased certainty to have lower case numbers for September than for June. 13 states already have surpassed their June value, some of which even earlier than projected.
4 indiscriminate states are currently in the "in-group"
11 states are currently on a stable path towards the "in-group"
10 more states are currently on a path towards the "in-group" as well, but with lowered certainty
The remaining 9 states are likely in an unchanged position within the margin of error (I haven't identified them yet), where the majority will see slight increases and, as a result, the June number of cases will be surpassed between 20 to 30 September 2020 as of now. As of now 34-37 (40 minus 10 plus 4 plus the "switching 3") states in total seem to belong to the "in-group" at the lowest, while the range extended to up to 47.
But:
In an environment with a US nationwide decline of new cases and an "deceleration/acceleration-ratio" of 1.33 (20 states and territories versus 15 s.a.t. of significance), it just seems to me that the overall variance in new cases has increased and the US as a whole and maybe half of the individual states may be at a turning point at this point in time. It remains to be seen, whether this turning (for the better or for the worse) will be sustainable and soon enough to affect the September case counts. And then there is a lot of overall uncertainty about effects of increased mask-wearing habits (potentially decelerating), schools and university campuses (potentially accelerating) and the labor day holiday weekend (potentially accelerating).
For now, I comfortably leave my forecast unchanged with the highest weight on bin 6.
MP and UT currently form an error band of (-2%/++2%) and are likely to continue to do so until MP has added 6 more cases and Utah starts showing any trend. Further data and analysis of the given data as of 09 September will follow in an [EDIT], when available. [EDIT:
My manual best guess-model, in which I also look at the historic graphs counts 10 states that are likely to deliver September figures lower than the June total. Most notably and unexpectedly NC and SC have seen such a large slump in case growth that I added them to the list. CT might be an 11th state, but it currently is directly on the brink. I also tried to formalize the estimate as of 09 September 2020 into a static, simplifying model as follows:
The model takes the period of 01 September to 09 September inclusively cutting it into two separate units, following my two most recent forecasts: 
A := number of total cases 01 to 05 September 2020 inclusively
B := number of total cases 06 to 09 September 2020 inclusively Although there is no reliability concerning representativeness for B as part of the whole month September (henceforth referred to to as "S"), I simply project S(e)= A + 6.25* B
under the assumption that the next 21 days or 5.25 periods of B (=4 days) will each result on average the same amount as B, and the assumption that deviations from B in single periods will (more or less) cancel each other over 5,25 periods. This approach is rather aggressive in a way that it overweights the most recent development and will amplify good as well as bad developments to the extreme. The caveat with this approach is that it basically assumes a flat 7 day average after 04 September 2020, which does not fit reality for most individual states, and it does not take into account trends, which are very important in a handful of states.
The projection, although I take it as one of many pieces of evidence, delivers a few new insights. First, it also counts SC to the "out-group", but contrary to my opinion, NC is currently in the "in-group" according to the model.
Secondly, it counts only 9 states in total (AZ, DC, FL, ME, MA, NH, NM, SC, VT) to be in the "out-group", which on the flipside means that the final result would be 46 states and territories, and the question would resolve on bin 7.
Further, I added the percentage values compared to the June 2020 total (referred to as "J") as follows:
(1) A*6/J
(2) B*7.5/J
(3) (A+B)*30/9*J The result underscores the importance of the future trend (which is why I don't take the result too seriously):

First of all there are 21 states that had more cases in August than in June. As of now (9/8), there are 7 states that ALREADY have more cases in September than they did in June.  We note that more cases are a byproduct of either a higher spread of cases OR simply higher testing rates. Given this, it is unsurprising to expect for many states to have higher case counts in September than in June, since testing rates have increased.  In thinking about actual spread, it is not unreasonable to believe that infection rates may be relatively the same as in June in most parts of the US. However, September has some characteristics that may affect these rates. Firstly, universities are open in many states, and it would not be surprising to see these affect the overall case numbers. Second, September is when season starts to turn to winter. Although it is still unknown how this affects the virus, it may lead to more people interacting indoors and thus an increase in cases. Based on a basic linear interpolation using the first 8 days of September data, 39 states are on pace to have more cases now than in June. This is unsurprisingly higher than the August number, and likely takes into account some of the factors mentioned. Using a similar approach to another gjopen question https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1681-on-1-september-2020-how-many-states-will-report-a-covid-19-positivity-rate-greater-than-10-0, we use the raw data from covidtracking.com as well as the visualizations presented on covidexitstrategy.org. Using raw data, we simulate changes in the "positive" field to arrive a final distribution. However, because we are forecasting a few weeks out, we see a wide variety of distributions that are highly sensitive to parameters used for the sim - specifically, we can take the standard deviation of positive changes over the last two weeks, vs the standard deviation over the past month, and get differing results.  Despite the variance in results, I am confident that a lower bound is ~30 states and an upper bound is ~45 states as my results fell largely within this range, with a skew to the higher end.

June vs Summer:
Even though we have little information about September, we can discuss what we have seen so far in July and August. In June most of the states were still relatively strict regarding their lockdown policies and most states have seen their lowest numbers of new cases. However, because of these trends, most states have reopened quite early and cases spiked everywhere in the month of July and August. I fitted AR models to each of the 55 states in this calculation and predicted the total case count for the month of September and then compared them to new case counts in June 2020. I get an EV of 39 states. 1 state is in the 0 to 100 higher (compared to June) estimate category, 1 state is in the 250 to 500 higher estimate category, 3 states are in the 500 to 1000 higher estimate category and 34 states are in the 1,000 higher estimate category. Thus we have at least 34 states that we deem as "safe" estimates (i.e. Sept. case counts will likely be higher than June). It is very unlikely that we will see less than 27 states and more than 44 states based on the number of edge cases (e.g. the number of states whose September numbers are less than June numbers by a max of 500 is zero). Thus, we put most of the weight in 36 - 43 bucket with some probability in the 28 - 35 bucket.

The COVID Tracking Project website data by state will determine the outcome of this challenge.  We can do the following calculation fairly easily.  Yes, it's a bit tedious, but shouldn't take more than about half an hour.  Subtract the cumulative number of positive tests on May 31 from the cumulative number of positive tests on June 30.  It's the data column labeled "cases."  Call the result J.  Divide the answer by 30 to get the average number of new cases for the month of June for each state. Now we can compare the daily positive tests for each state to that state's June average.  [Better still to use the current 7-day average of positive tests.]  At the present time there are only 10 states that are seeing average new cases below their respective June averages.  If nothing were to change the answer would be 55 - 10 = 45.  But of course things are changing every day. By my count there are 24 states that are so far above their June averages that it is a virtual certainty that S > J.  Reinfection rates would have to fall to something like 0.5 for new case numbers to decrease that drastically.  That seems unlikely.  [Alternatively we would have to stop testing.  This also seems unlikely.]  An additional 8 states are more likely than not to see S > J.  There are only three states that look very likely to see S <  J (AZ, FL & NH). Lastly, by my count there are about a dozen states that are too close to call.  These states could quickly flip either way, e.g., look at IA.  Over the past week the 7-day average has nearly doubled.  Prior to this past week it looked like IA could go either way.  Now it's a virtual certainty that S > J for IA. My conclusion is that it is much more likely that a state will see a rapid increase in new cases than a rapid decrease.  Based on the above I estimate that the answer will be 42 states.  But there is still a fair amount of uncertainty in this estimate.  Since 42 is close to the boundary between the two highest buckets I'll split my chips between those two.

The CDC has been doing seroprevalence studies in several geographies in the US.  See https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/commercial-lab-surveys.html The New York City study was widely reported in the media.  I was not aware of the other studies, but a Google search for "covid antibody surveys" quickly found the above link. The NYC study estimated that there were ten times as many people with antibodies as there were confirmed infections.  If that were true then states like AZ and LA would be approaching some limited amount of herd immunity.  There have been numerous articles about the possibility of herd immunity.  See for example https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2020/07/herd-immunity-coronavirus/614035/ I believe Louisiana has the highest number of confirmed cases as a percentage of the state's population (3.1%).  The serology study estimated about two times that percentage had antibodies (5.8%, with an error band of 3.9 to 8.2%).  So for LA the ratio of people with antibodies to confirmed cases was much less that the 10 to 1 ratio that got a lot of publicity after the NYC study.  The same appears to be true for the other locations, e.g., CT, that were included in the COVID antibody surveys.  The ratio appears to be closer to two to one, not 10 to one. I am now much less optimistic that any kind of herd immunity will slow the virus' spread.  The vaccine, if it works, is the only way to get to herd immunity in less than 3 years.  Bummer! So I'm moving further up the ladder on this question.  I'm also putting some chips on "44 or more" on the theory that there could be a spike after the end of summer partying during Labor Day weekend.

The number of coronavirus cases spiked in July, currently the last couple of weeks have been seeing a downtick in cases. However, levels are still higher than those in June. According to npr (https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2020/03/16/816707182/map-tracking-the-spread-of-the-coronavirus-in-the-u-s) 33 states have recorded a decline in new cases since 2 weeks ago. With many states shelter in place orders expiring and many school districts planning for a mixed in-person/online start in September, I would expect cases to increase near the end of September given the 2 week incubation period of coronavirus.

In order to determine whether the total count for September will be above June for a given state we have to determine whether the average level in September will be above the average level in June.  To establish our base rate we can compare current levels to average June levels. As of August 9, case counts are increasing in 9 states according to the NYT covid tracker. 5/9 of these have current levels above average levels from June. Cases are mostly the same in 22 states of which 11 are discernibly above June levels. Finally, 21 states have decreasing counts and about 12 are above June levels. The question is which of these states will remain above June levels on average through September and which of the states outside this group will enter into this group by next month. Glancing through the state daily new case curves, it seems like a state requires at least 1.5 months to complete a spike cycle. The states where case counts are decreasing have enough time to fall below June averages throughout September. In states where counts are increasing they will probably remain above June levels through September which gives us 5. For states where counts are about the same it's unclear whether cases will fall fast enough by then so I would estimate about half of the cases with above June levels will have more cases in September - 5.5. Still, because states appear unwilling to impose full lockdowns, it may take longer than before a for a case cycle to go through so I would adjust up slightly and add a few states in the decreasing category. Furthermore, there are some states where counts are lower than June but are increasing in counts that may be above by September so I would add the rest of the group where cases are increasing and levels look to be greater than June by September bringing us to around 20 for an expected value with decent variance around this estimate

When accounting for the 2-14 day incubation period, for COVID-19 infection rates to fall for September, both the current infection and transmission rates must fall. This has not been the trend, as 1.9 million cases were reported in July, the highest monthly since the beginning of the pandemic. In the last 14 days, there has been a rise in cases in 9 states, a decrease in 17, and stagnation in 24. Per NYT coronavirus data, about 10 states in the western US (Montana, Idaho, Wyoming, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, New Mexico, North Dakota, South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas) are experiencing very few cases - and have not changed significantly since the onset of the virus in the US, thus making the 44< and 36-44 cases relatively unlikely. Using the website endcoronavirus.org, we look at the 3 groupings, which are 'need to take action' , 'nearly there', and 'beat I self assigned probabilities to each of the states and territories based on the shapes of these graphs and my impressions of the states. I then assumed that we could treat each of these states as a bernoulli variable with my p, and then noted that the sum of all these variables would be my distribution. I then calculated the mean and variance of this distribution, and then eyeballed the probabilities (Since this distirbution, known as the poisson binomial distribution does not have easily available calculators/visualizers online). As of 7/27/2020, we have reached the inflection point for the second wave of COVID-19 cases. The second derivative for the number of cases for this second wave was positive for roughly 7 weeks, so there is more than enough time for the number of daily cases to remain higher throughout August and September.  However, it is important to recognize the vast majority of new cases are localized to within a few states - essentially, all the states with large populations that initially weathered the first wave well have surged in cases (mean reversion) but are now slowing down. Due to this current uncertainty, I will be flattening my curve in anticipation while monitoring the growth models to look for a future move.

First, to establish a baseline - we should check how many states daily new cases are above June levels. Based on the NYTimes state-level maps, 43 states are currently seeing daily new cases on the rise. For almost all of these states, daily new cases are above levels seen in June because the end of May was the trough of the 'first wave' before reopening in most of those states. Next, we should check what the lifecycle of a case resurgence looks like. Based on the initial wave of cases in the states with the most serious outbreaks (NY, CT, NJ, DC etc.) a cycle takes above 2-3 months to run its course with a reasonable amount of variance. Thus, we can expect states that started to resurge in mid-June as reopening commenced to be at the tail end of their cycles. This would cause us to move our estimate downwards from the baseline of low-40's. But two important context specific factors bake me keep my distribution centered fairly high in the upper 30's. First, though some states like California have been willing to reinstitute lockdown policies due to the second wave, most other state governors have not been willing to do so. Still, even if lockdown-esque policies are put in place, rates of testing are much higher so even if test-positivity rates are lower, the raw number of cases will be higher than before simply because we are catching more cases. The policy variable does add the most uncertainty to my estimate though which is why I put decent probability on all outcomes from 12-35 states below my max of 36-43. State governors are increasingly encouraging the use of masks and mask usage in the US is on the rise. It is possible that as masks become more widespread, we reach a point at which we see substantial reductions in new cases without states having to go into full lockdowns. This variable is uncertain both from a policy perspective, a cultural perspective, and a public health efficacy perspective.

Covid-19 According to this question, there are 55 states in the US. My analysis refers to data which involves only the 50 US States + DC. I will therefore scale up my final numbers by 55/51 for my final result. The most important nuance to this question is that the number of infected individuals currently far exceeds the number of reported cases because of low gross testing rates. Higher rates of testing will reveal more cases, especially once more asymptotic cases are tested. For that reason, if the replication factor remains 1, and the number of infected individuals remains the same in each state, there will be far more reported cases in the fall, assuming testing rates increase. According to the NY Times, 34/50 states are below the standard testing threshold determined by the Harvard Global Health Institute. Nationwide, 690,000 tests are being conducted each day. The goal is ~2,000,000 daily tests. The US is currently testing only at ~35% of its target figure each day. Under-testing in the US not only accelerates the spread of the virus due to poor detection of cases, it will result in higher reported figures in later months when testing is ramped up. However, I am not insinuating that with 3x as many tests we would report 3x many cases. Testing has diminishing marginal returns; data shows that with each additional test, the “positive test rate” decreases. The degree to which this testing rate disparity influences reporting is unclear. By examining positive test rates and gross testing rates in the US currently, a prediction on the degree of current underreporting can be made. Assuming by September gross testing targets are met, case detection could increase by 20-50%. Another complicating factor is that there is a real disparity between gross testing rates in different states. 14 states are currently exceeding testing targets. 3 states are at testing targets. However, these 17 states that have robust testing were more likely to have experienced a bad first wave of coronavirus.  We can think of dividing states into two categories: those which experienced a major March/April wave of infection, and those which did not.  From statewide data provided by the NY Times, we can determine some characteristics about these two categories, as well as which states belong to them. States with a March/April infection peak: 14 identified: 
CT, DC, DE, IL*, LA*, MA, MD, ME, NH, NJ, NY, PA, RI, VT (*= not in Northeast) -These states experienced mass infection in spring, then a steep drop off ever since.
-These states typically have robust testing.
-These states are concentrated in the Northeast, and have similar climates (hot summer, cold winter)
-June infection numbers were generally very low, and September will bring cooler weather, and the likely re-opening of schools
-Schools and colleges are likely to be open in some capacity this fall
-More re-openings are underway for these states, causing more infections Determining a base rate for these states is somewhat unclear, due to lack of historic data. However, I suggest that if these states have reached a steady state of infections, we would expect 50% of them to have a higher September total than June total (so 7). Because of the above reasons, however, I am assuming that the number of states with higher infection numbers in September than in June will be normally distributed around 9.8 (70% of 14), with a standard deviation of 3, assuming a 2/3’s chance of this number being between 7 and 13.  States with a (roughly) monotonic increase since March 1, or a small March/April peak: This category includes the other 37 states.  -This category is more heterogeneous
-Typically, gross testing rates are well below targets.
-With no massive first wave, the governments of these states have underestimated the dangers of the novel coronavirus
-These states (mostly) reported large infection numbers in June.
-Re-openings began early but are now being paused (in some states).
-In three months, it is likely that re-openings will be advancing once again. As a base rate, 50% of 37 is 18.5. I except by September 1st, gross testing rates will increase significantly, and a second reopening will full speed ahead. However, some of these states reported extremely high June infection numbers, which will be difficult to surpass. Because of this, I predict that in 55% of states in this category, we will see an increase in Novel Coronavirus cases. I predict that this can be expected to be normally distributed around 20, with a standard deviation of 7, due to the high uncertainty in this category. In order to come up with a final prediction, we must combine these two categories. My prediction is that the number of States (out of 51) that will have more cases in September than in June will be 30, with a standard deviation of 7.6 (sqrt(7^2 + 3^2)). To make this distribution valid for 55 states, both the mean and the standard deviation need to be increased by 55/51 for the final distribution ~ N(32,8). I then manually, slightly adjusted the distribution (primarily to account for unconsidered uncertainty) to come up with by final result: <4 - 0%
4-11 - 3%
12-19 - 8%
20-27 - 24%
28-35 - 35%
36-43 - 24%
>44 - 6% Currently we can assume that there will be no vaccine by Sept. 2020. Therefore, containment of the virus will be solely dependent on social distancing and using PPE.

I have adjusted my forecast upwards to reflect the increased probability of a second wave of cases in many of the 55 US states. New cases and deaths have also not slowed at a rate comparable to other countries, even in states that have not experienced a second wave. My initial forecast had considered different groups of states. 6 states that either seemed to be reaching their peaks (CA, TX, FL, AZ) or had strict reopening guidelines in place (NY, NJ) and therefore assigned a 15% chance to have more cases. 10 states that were politically more aggressive in reopening, with 80% chance to have more cases. 15 states that were politically more inclined to caution and restrictions, with 30% chance to have more cases. The remaining 24 states I assigned 30% chance if cases were trending downwards, and 70% chance if trending upwards. Finally, I reflected that the tails would be larger, given that states are not independent; the development of a vaccine or treatment, or a nation-wide second wave, would shift all states up or down.

I have adjusted my forecast based on new information between Jun. 28th and Jul. 11th. Around the end of June 2020 we observed a sharp increase in COVID-19 cases and it continuously break daily new cases record. Yesterday, July 11th, we have seen over 70k new COVID cases across United States. It is still unknown to us how the second wave will play out and how long the new cases increase will last. However, even if the upward trend for new cases is quickly controlled, it doesn’t mean new cases will disappear overnight. Based on the first wave reaction in United States, we observe that the new cases capped around April 1st and hovered at essentially the same level for about 2 months and a half. Right now, state governments are essentially doing similar things to manage the spread of second wave COVID, as they do to manage the first wave. Therefore, it is highly probable that we will observe the new cases curve plateaued (higher daily number than June 2020) rather than sharply dropped to zero and I assign such probability 70%. In this case, if we assume all states are independent, then the base mean for the number of states to have higher number of cases in September than June is 38.5. So I put my initial distribution’s mean around that number.  However, after going through each state’s data, most of the new cases are concentrated in a number of states (AZ, CA, TX, FL, account for ~1/2 new cases), therefore I adjust my mean/median downward to 25. Considering my previous reasoning, current situation is leaning more to the negative side, therefore I gave my updated forecast as a distribution skew to the left.

My prior is 22.7. This is fairly crudely calculated via 50% odds * 55 states. I selected 50% because I have very little insight into this matter. Because of my baseline level of insight, I can minimize my brier score by selection 50%. Of course I could break the problem down into more manageable chunks like Marc suggested in the last lecture, but I will do that in the likelihood calculations and adjust this prior.  My likelihood calculations are more optimistic than the prior calculations. Given that it took hard hit areas like China and New York roughly 3 months to go "up and down the mountain" in Cuomo's words, the peak of each state's number of infected was roughly at the 1.5 month mark. Given that the aggressive growth rates of infection in harder hit states mirror NY's rates in the early few weeks, I am setting June 1st 2020 as week 1. This anchor point is flexible (you can shift it back ~1 month in the following analysis remain valid). Therefore, 3 months past Week 1 should return the state to levels near the beginning. This will be approximately August 31.  Given that the question is asking for a measurement in cases/ month, we see the month of August mirror June with a negative second derivative in terms of infection rates. Therefore, September numbers will be lower than August. Since June = August and September < August, September < June. Therefore, the mean for my post-likelihood adjusted numbers will be < 27.5.  I set the distribution to still be centered around 20-27 though. This is because the examples I used in my likelihood calculation took strict measures for containment. Many of the flare up cases are from conservative states whose residents are more likely to resist "big government" orders. Therefore, I shift the center of gravity of my distribution from 12-19 to 20-27.  These calculations are even despite a potential vaccine being developed. This is because initial manufacturing ramp up of the vaccine are likely to be slow as with any mass-scale manufacturing process (despite some efforts from Bill Gates and other US Gov't entities trying to get a jump start on manufacturing).

Updated Forecast based on latest Covid-19 cases data on 07/08/2020: U.S. Cases Rise 2% 
Coronavirus cases in the U.S. rose 59,655 from a day earlier to 3.02 million, according to data collected by Johns Hopkins University and Bloomberg News. The 2% increase was higher than the average daily increase of 1.8% over the past week. Deaths rose 0.8% to 131,857.
Florida reported 223,783 cases, up 4.7% from a day earlier, less than the verage increase of 5% in the previous seven days. Deaths reached 3,889, a 1.2% rise.
Arizona had 3,520 new cases, bringing that state’s total to 108,614, a 3.3% increase that was below the prior seven-day average of 4.1%. California Cases Hit One-Day Record
California reported 11,694 new virus cases, its largest one-day increase and above the seven-day average of 8,116 daily infections. The state had 111 additional deaths, The rate of positive tests over the past 14 days has jumped to 7.1%, compared with around 5% two weeks ago. The number of virus patients in intensive-care unit beds rose to 358 from 343. Patients on ventilators jumped to 184 from 175 a day earlier and was at the highest since April 20, according to the county’s daily report on Wednesday, based on self-reporting by hospitals. U.S. Cases Top 3 Million 
The number of confirmed cases in the U.S. has surpassed 3 million, representing more than a quarter of all cases globally, according to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University. As of noon New York time, the U.S. had 3,009,611 confirmed and 131,594 deaths, the school reported. Arizona reported 3,520 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the state’s total to 108,614, a 3.3% increase that was below the prior seven-day average of 4.1%. The state Department of Health Services also reported 36 new deaths, raising that toll to 1,963. Florida Cases Climb by 4.7% 
Florida reported 223,783 Covid-19 cases on Wednesday, up 4.7% from a day earlier, compared with an average increase of 5% in the previous seven days. Deaths rose by 48 to 3,889, an increase of 1.2%, according to the report, which includes data through Tuesday. Cumulative hospitalizations of Florida residents rose by 333, a 2% rise to 16,758. Meanwhile, the new rate of people testing positive for the first time fell to 14.2% for Tuesday, from 16.2% a day earlier. The median age of cases among residents fell by a year to 39.

Given this format of question, there are 55 states total, so if each state was a 50% chance of being higher or lower, I'd expect 27.5 to have more cases in September.  It might seem ridiculous to approximate this as 50%, but I am having trouble weighting arguments in favor of rising numbers (such as some experts predict) and arguments in favor of declining numbers (such as mean reversion in currently highly-infected states). These states' cases certainly have some degree of correlation, so the probability of a large deviance from my predicted mean was non-negligible. I made my low tail somewhat higher overall than my high tail, as certain events that would cause a low tail (such as a new discovered treatment), seemed more likely than events that would cause a high tail (such as every state going in free-for-all mode).

In first approximation, I expect the infection rate to increase significantly in the country overall as lockdowns are relaxed, schools reopen, and people return to work.  In the past week alone new infections have increased more than 30%.  This establishes a baseline: I predict the infection rate overall will be much higher in September. Some states will certainly reimpose restrictions as cases increase dramatically, but I expect the political will to shutter all nonessential businesses again to be much lower than it was in March/April in most states.  Even in those that do reimpose severe restrictions, for most states June has been a low point for infections thus far, coming after two full months of lockdown.  Even if some degree of lockdown is reimposed after a month or two of reopening, the new case rate will likely not immediately fall to its previous minimum (especially considering that the virus will have spread significantly by that point). Key pieces of evidence that would work against this analysis:
-  A demonstration in multiple states that leaders are prepared to very quickly reimpose complete lockdown 
-  Development of a vaccine (highly unlikely on this time frame)
-  Signs that increased testing and contact tracing are highly effective at reducing infections (at a scale comparable to previous lockdowns) Finally it is also important to note that states will likely be highly correlated, so this forecast should be updated fairly aggressively as new data becomes available.

About 15 states currently have a positive second derivative in new cases (number of new cases is increasing at a faster rate each day). It takes around 1.5-2 months for a severe spike cycle to reverse assuming lockdown policies are implemented and adhered to. Many regions in the US have culturally and psychologically ‘decided’ that living with the virus is permissible and the costs of severe lockdown are too high. Thus, a fair number of these states may have more cases in September than now. Furthermore, cooling temperatures alongside the reopening of schools will not help. The fat tail reflects the chance that we see this phenomenon become widespread as even states that were successful in suppressing the first wave experience a letup. Still, there is a reasonable chance that testing and tracing do actually become institutionalized throughout the states in which case only a small number of states will have more cases. The wide distribution reflects the uncertainty around the relative probabilities of these scenarios.

Points in favor:
 - Second waves are likely to be localized as inter-state travel remains mostly on lockdown. Thus, the correlation of timing and magnitude of second waves in different states should be much less than in March.
- Multiple second waves in Florida, Texas, California, and Arizona occurring in June, inflating the case numbers for states with large, concentrated cities likely to be easily targeted by Covid.
- Expect governments in the above mentioned states to take lessons from reopening procedures (opening bars and not mandating face masks in Florida, Texas can partially explain the resurgence)
- Potential for a therapy to be released over the next 2 months (a vaccine appears to be very unlikely).
- Incentive for Trump and Republican-aligned state governments to avoid testing in large quantities the month before election, possibly under-representing true case numbers.
- Many work places have already adopted policies to not return to work until 2021 or after September 2020. Research has indicated productivity has remained fairly high.
- Many states are highly rural and protected from Covid, especially with lack of inter-state travel (<25% of year ago TSA checkpoint visits)
- States will shut down faster than March, as we know the consequences now. Points against:
- Mass testing likely to be even more ubiquitous in September
- People will become more restless if forced to quarantine for an additional two months.
- September aligns with return to higher education (universities) as well as K-12 schools. Students face smaller risks as compared to older generations, and are more likely to take risks, including not quarantining. In addition, smaller towns and cities dominated by pro-Trump sentiment may ignore possible risks, as Covid has become a political issue. This is backed by polls. Another poll of parents indicates up to 60% of them are considering home learning options, but this is a non-committal stance and is also likely to be correlated based on region.
- It took about 2 months for states to start reopening, thus prodding this second wave in the states mentioned earlier.
- Possible mutation of Covid adds tail risk
- 75% of executives said around 50% of workers would be back in office by September 1st in a June 24 poll. However, this is stale news in the face of new Covid case spikes, so this is likely to change. Conclusion: Evidence seems to point towards less than 15 states seeing higher case counts, as they take greater precautions and learn from the 1.5th wave of Arizona, Texas Florida, and California. Rural states will see more lax restrictions, but also with the natural protection of more spread out spaces. It is important to bear in mind that these predictions bear large tail risk, as Covid itself is a very high volatility event.

Estimates for individual states based on the current trend. However, the probabilities for individual states should be highly correlated as are the number of positive test cases. The highest variance assuming independence of probabilities for states is just 13.75 while the highest possible variance is 252 (assuming uniform distribution across all possible states). Without dependence, the extreme cases will be extremely unlikely which is unreasonable given that there is a lot of variability in the possible scenarios that can occur in the next 2 months (although they still should be considered improbable). Also, the eventual increase in the test numbers should increase the number of positives which would otherwise be undetected because of the lack of symptoms. Many states with a low or moderate number of test cases might focus more on opening the economy which will result in the increase of cases (even if it will be tiny, it will still count towards the forecasted value) - this suggests that the mean of the distribution should be rather high (around 20). The specific probabilities are derived through the MC simulation based on simple assumptions and rough estimates.

First approximation to the problem: this question at first seems intractable, but it can be effectively treated in a relatively simple manner by assuming a constant probability for each state to have more cases in September than in June and then doing a normal distribution. For the purposes of the question we have 55 "states" (the 50 standard ones + the 5 added in the description). If we assume a probability p of having more cases, the per bucket probability can be readily obtained using for instance this Mathematica code: 100 (CDF[BinomialDistribution[55, p], 35] - 
   CDF[BinomialDistribution[55, p], 27]) where I am using the 28 to 35 bucket for illustrative purposes. The problem is of course "what is the probability p?" and I have not made my mind about it. I have simply assumed a 50% chance as a first approximation.  @Dillyweed has made a more detailed discussion in one of his predictions [1], settling on a 60%, pretty similar to my flip coin estimation. However this would lead to the following distribution of the buckets: {0 , 0 ,0, 7,  69, 24, 0} This means that this question is particularly sensitive to the estimation of the average probability of a state having more cases in September than in June. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1063860

The virus has shown no signs of waning, and has in fact, begun to return in second waves in more than one part of the world. This is to say, that simply reducing restrictions within countries has led to, albeit smaller, second waves. The question of a second or third wave, is not a question of “if,” but one of “when.” The answer? The regular cold and flu season, which, year after year, is in the fall and winter months, when our immune systems are more susceptible to influenzae and coronaviruses. This virus will be no different, and a vaccine is still a long way out, regardless of what our governments and media portray. A vaccine developed, and tested, and successful, completed within one year, would be unprecedented, as it has never been done. Ever. Therefore, the vast majority of states, and countries worldwide, are highly likely to see cases explode in the next cold and flu season, unless further restrictions for social distancing are put in place long beforehand.

Infection rates are already going up, with most states now reopening to various degrees. The question is how local governments and individuals will respond to these increases. I believe “pandemic fatigue” will be a significant factor in the decisions for both, particularly as we become more accustomed to (and comfortable with) routine reports of deaths in the thousands. The course of the pandemic so far suggests that undetected (untested and never reported) community spread can require a significant time period (months) before resulting in the kind of widespread transmission that can’t be overlooked. Testing and and contract tracing are the key tools to avoid this trap, but there isn’t nearly enough of it occurring, and that seems likely to persist, given the lack of support and coordination being offered by our federal government. More cases in September than June is a pretty low bar to clear, so I am fairly confident that it will be the case in most places. The bigger unknown is how testing will unfold. It’s unfortunate, but in some states, political beliefs could have a significant impact on whether sufferers choose to be tested and counted, as is already the case with the use of face masks. Testing in general may fall out of favor in some states, with availability poor and political incentives to keep it that way. The other uncertainty for me involves timing. Numbers may or may not dip in the summer, with people often outdoors. And random chance will also play its part, given the proportion of COVID-19 transmission that can be attributed to individual superspreader events. September may be too specific a time frame for the overall trends I expect to see.

I think the only way to tackle this is with a state-by-state approach. I tried to classify based on how likely I thought it was that the state would have more cases in September than June [1]. This was not too rigorous, but states hit hard (with a decent amount of immunity ~20-30%, NY, NJ) were seen as less likely. Also, states with a decent amount of infections and increasing new cases I think are less likely (California, Texas, Virginia, North Carolina) [2]. States with few current cases were seen as more of a toss-up. I did not calculate these as independent variables, because I think they are going to be correlated, with most of the uncertainty coming from my estimate of the likelihood of each group. So, I tried to capture that by estimating a 20% range for each of the groupings. For example, the "lean no" grouping had between 25 and 45% chance of more cases in September than June. This process gave an answer between 10 and 21, but I skewed a bit lower because I think the possibility of a surprise lack of infection going forward is more likely than a surprise increase in infection. Also, re-opening is in full swing so we'll likely see the "more infection" surprise earlier rather than later, if it were to occur.  Other factors influencing this are the current protests, which favor more cases in June. On the other hand, more testing by September should offset this. This, combined with existing stay-at-home measures and public awareness, may keep the Rt in the 1-1.1 range that it's at now (see https://epiforecasts.io/covid/posts/global/) for perhaps the next month or two — at best, maybe through the entire summer. This is not influenza and I'm not sure if it makes sense to describe what may await us in the fall as a "second wave" — but whatever it is, I am not optimistic for the prospects of most of the country but for hard-hit states in the northeast (which will presumably take any uptick in cases very seriously) and cautious states on the west coast (which are proving themselves to be slow to lift stay-at-home measures, and thus will also presumably be more willing reimpose them if need be).

We are asked to compare a set of numbers that we don't know with another set of numbers that we don't know.  Interesting! What we do know is that (probably) the number of infections in June will be less than May.  Even this assumption could prove to be false if premature "reopening" increases infection.  But we have to make some assumptions if we don't want to just randomly assign probabilities.  I will assume that July and August will bring decreasing numbers, and that reemergence of SARS-COV-2 will not happen quickly in the fall.  That would imply few states with worse numbers for September than for June.  I will overweight the lower numbers vis a vis the crowd. How could this forecast go wrong?  One scenario is that some of the mostly rural states that haven't had many cases don't take the threat seriously.  E.g., it wouldn't take a huge flair up in Wyoming to have a bigger problem in September than in June.  Children returning to school could be the vectors for a resurgence of the virus.

Assumption #1 is that testing capacity will be slightly higher in Sept than June. Assumption #2 is that some kind of second wave emerges, though that could happen at any point between August and the end of the year, really. Assumption #3 is that the US is more prepared for another wave, which kind of offsets the effects of assumption #1. Lots of uncertainty for now, so priors will need updating.

Fundamentally the states will hang together. There is so much interstate travel and shipping, I have trouble believing that a single state's policies will protect them from a neighboring state's policies.   Very few governments around the world have been able to prevent the spread of this illness, which is fatal to around 1-4% of the population. The methods used to prevent the spread are anathema to American ideals in the abstract, and by the time deaths move into a locality, it's about 4 weeks too late to really contain the virus.  After 4 weeks of lockdown, which by the fall will have been off and on and sometimes in force and sometimes not enforced.... There will only be partial compliance even once death comes to town.  I think infection and death rates will grind higher through the fall.      However, I think another possibility is that the death rates are more like .1% and the virus is much more widespread than we currently think.  If that is the case, the case rate will raise slightly after the lockdown is ended, and we will all be pleasantly surprised at how well we are all doing.  Even then, I expect more *cases* unless we stop keeping track.

Interesting question. Initial impression: 
1) what will case totals be for June? My guess is that in general they will be much lower for most states than for April and May. My guess is that we will still be benefiting from social distancing and people taking this seriously.
2) what will the case totals be for September? Much harder to estimate. My guess is that in general they will be about the same as in June or higher as people let down their guard on social distancing and start working and vacationing more. Still, I think having nearly all states higher in Sept than in June also seems unlikely.  Although the numbers are still in dispute, I believe that there's still something like 95%+ of the population that has not yet been exposed, so there is a lot of fertile ground for this thing to continue to spread.  So I'm going to bet somewhat higher than the rest of the crowd I follow.
